awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Efficient power generation with zero emissions using a novel thermodynamic cycle: the Argon power cycle.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation – Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project addresses deteriorating air quality in urban areas and increased energy demand. The proposed core technology is a new thermodynamic power cycle for power generation with high efficiency, while producing no air pollutants. This new technology will offer an affordable and reliable power source.

The proposed project addresses the challenge faced by the power sector regarding the intermittency of renewable energy: an increasing demand for cost-competitive, clean dispatchable power. This new demand can be met by a breakthrough in power generation technology called the Argon Power Cycle (APC). This project will conduct experimental and theoretical studies to demonstrate this technology's capability to deliver higher energy conversion efficiencies through the engineering and assembly of a laboratory argon power cycle prototype, design and development of dedicated controls, and integration of membrane gas separation technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addresses a broad worldwide issue in the energy field: the conservation of our environment and air quality, while simultaneously providing reliable and affordable electricity that the global economy needs to thrive. The core technology is a new thermodynamic power cycle that increases the power generation efficiency of internal combustion engines by using argon as the working fluid. The main study focuses on the demonstration of a Argon Power Cycle (APC) unit that allows separation of carbon dioxide from exhaust flue gas with high degree of selectivity, but minimum energy loss and low cost.  A completely new experimental lab was set up to explore technologies to overcome three technical barriers: (1) efficient power generation, (2) cost-effective recovery of carbon dioxide, and (3) stable operation regime.  In parallel to laboratory tests, advanced numerical models were developed for exploration and validation of optimal operation conditions. Through extensive laboratory tests and advanced numerical modeling, the key findings are: 1) By optimizing engine intake conditions, stable engine operation was achieved over a very wide range of operating conditions which are wider than originally anticipated; 2) High engine operating efficiency is reached and it surpassed our expectations. Specifically the thermodynamics efficiency reaches values as high as 30% gain over air cycle; 3) Parametric studies of engine simulations provided critical guidance toward optimal operation conditions to overcome engine stability issue; 4) Simulation results from a membrane separation model integrated with the complete operation of the unit suggested that capture of CO2  more than 90% is feasible. These extensive laboratory and simulation results for the APC have accelerated and translated the development efforts from proof of concepts to a full integrated prototype that validate the commercial viability of the proposed technology.
